title: Rocket Propellant Systems
description: Chemical rocket propellant combinations: primary orbital fuels, green alternatives, high-density mixtures, metal additives, peroxide systems, ammonia/nitrate systems, and exotic super-energetics. Includes performance metrics, storability, reuse potential, and development status.

categories.name: Green Hypergolic Propellants
categories.description: Hypergolic fuels ignite spontaneously with oxidizer, ideal for restartable engines and spacecraft maneuvering. Traditional hypergols (UDMH + N2O4) are toxic; these newer green alternatives reduce hazard and cost.

propellants.name: LMP-103S + NOFBX/MON
challenges: Still not as high Isp as LH2

categories.name: High-Density Energetic Mixtures
categories.description: Fuel blends that trade a little Isp for much higher density and simpler tanks. Advantageous for compact designs or high thrust applications.

categories.name: Metal Additives / Powdered Fuels
categories.description: Adding reactive metals to propellant increases energy density (MJ/kg), potentially boosting effective thrust and performance. Mostly research curiosities — promising for boosters or special stages.

categories.name: Peroxide-Based Systems
categories.description: High-concentration hydrogen peroxide used as an oxidizer or monopropellant. Storable at room temperature, non-toxic compared to N2O4. Used in rockets like the British Black Arrow and many small launchers.

categories.name: Ammonia / Nitrate Systems
categories.description: Ammonia and related compounds are easy to store and handle. Not competitive for heavy orbital work, but potential for flight control thrusters, small launcher stages, or green hardware platforms.

categories.name: Exotic Super-Energetics (Experimental)
categories.description: Early research or speculative propellant concepts. Most are far from flight readiness due to stability, handling, combustion control, or safety issues.
concepts: Metalized boron fuels — ultra high energy
Hypergolic ionic liquids with enhanced performance
Nano-structured propellants with tailored burn properties

comparison.description: Performance comparison across all major propellant systems

systems.name: Methalox / LOX
systems.notes: New reusable favorite, best all-around replacement for kerosene

systems.name: Green Hypergols (AF-315E etc.)
systems.notes: Restartable stages, satellite propulsion, spacecraft maneuvering

selectionCriteria.description: Key criteria a propellant must meet to replace methalox or hydrolox on a primary orbital booster
selectionCriteria.verdict: None of the alternative propellants hit all criteria without tradeoffs. Methalox is currently the best all-around replacement for kerosene boosters, balancing performance, density, and reuse.
